questions.question: Explain common cathode vs common anode 7-segment display.

answers.a: Common cathode has all grounds connected; common anode has all positives connected.
answers.b: Common cathode uses analog signals; common anode uses digital signals.
answers.d: Common anode works only with AC supply.

explanations.a: Correct: CC = shared ground, CA = shared +V.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Both have same number of pins.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Both work on DC low voltage.

questions.question: How can Arduino generate multiple colors on an RGB LED?

answers.a: By mixing PWM signals on the red, green, and blue pins.
answers.c: By connecting it to analog input pins.

explanations.a: Correct: PWM allows brightness control → mixed colors.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Voltage alone cannot create colors.
explanations.c: Incorrect: RGB LEDs require output pins.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Rotation does not affect color.

questions.question: Why is OLED preferred in modern IoT dashboards?

answers.a: It consumes low power and gives high contrast display.
answers.d: It works only in dark conditions.

explanations.a: Correct: OLED is bright, low-power, and great for visuals.
explanations.c: Incorrect: OLED can display text, graphics, icons.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Works in all lighting conditions.

questions.question: Describe the internal working of an LCD 16×2.

answers.a: It uses a controller (HD44780) to drive characters in a dot matrix.
answers.b: It displays text using OLED pixels.
answers.c: It stores each character in RAM permanently.
answers.d: It uses LEDs behind every character.

explanations.a: Correct: LCD uses HD44780 controller + dot matrix.
explanations.b: Incorrect: OLED is a different display tech.
explanations.d: Incorrect: LEDs are used only for backlight.

questions.question: How can you display sensor data on LCD?

answers.a: Read sensor → convert to value → use lcd.print().
answers.b: Write sensor data directly to the LCD pins.
answers.d: Use the LCD to sense data.

explanations.a: Correct: Sensor reading + lcd.print() shows data.

questions.question: What is the difference between active and passive buzzer?

answers.a: Active buzzer has built-in oscillator; passive needs tone() to generate sound.
answers.c: Active buzzer can read input signals.
answers.d: Both work only with analog input.

explanations.a: Correct: Active = simple ON/OFF tone. Passive = multi-tone via PWM.
explanations.d: Incorrect: They work on digital signals.

questions.question: How does I2C communication reduce pin usage?

answers.a: It uses only two lines (SDA, SCL) for multiple devices.
answers.c: It converts analog pins into digital pins.

explanations.a: Correct: I2C allows many devices on same two wires.
explanations.b: Incorrect: I2C does not disable pins.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Pin function does not change.

questions.question: What happens when incorrect wiring is done for 7-segment display?

answers.a: Some segments will glow incorrectly or not at all.
answers.b: It will automatically correct the connection.
answers.c: It will display all numbers perfectly.

explanations.a: Correct: Wrong wiring → wrong segments lit.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Wrong wiring cannot display correctly.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Only short circuits may affect Arduino.

questions.question: Give a real-life application of buzzer in IoT.

explanations.a: Correct: Buzzers are used for alerts in IoT devices.
explanations.b: Incorrect: Streaming devices do not use buzzers.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Weather displays do not alert with buzzers.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Street lights do not use buzzers.

questions.question: How can brightness of RGB LED be controlled in simulation?

answers.a: By using PWM output through analogWrite() on each color pin.

explanations.a: Correct: PWM controls brightness of R, G, B channels.
explanations.b: Incorrect: digitalRead does not control output.
explanations.c: Incorrect: Serial Monitor cannot change LED brightness.
explanations.d: Incorrect: Wiring position doesn’t control brightness.
